questions.text: Identify the sign. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Double ring sign

 

The image shows a radiograph with a distinct double ring appearance, which is characteristic of a button battery. A button battery has a three-dimensional structure with two concentric rings when viewed on X-ray, creating the "double ring sign." This appearance is diagnostic of a button battery, a common foreign object seen in pediatric radiographs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. String sign: The string sign refers to a thin, string-like narrowing often associated with conditions like Crohn's disease or hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. It does not have the double ring appearance seen in this image.

 

Option C. Bird beak sign: The bird beak sign is associated with achalasia and appears as a tapering of the distal esophagus resembling a bird's beak. This sign does not resemble the double ring pattern shown in the image.

 

Option D. Double bubble sign: This sign is associated with duodenal atresia and appears as two bubbles (the stomach and the proximal duodenum) on an X-ray. It is distinct from the double ring pattern seen with a button battery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "double ring sign" on an X-ray is characteristic of a button battery, easily distinguishable by its unique appearance.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with dragging pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is massive splenomegaly. Peripheral smear shows leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes and basophils. Which of the following translocation is seen in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) t (9:22)

 

Massive splenomegaly and a peripheral smear showing leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and basophils are symptoms of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). This condition is characterized by a translocation between t (9;22).

 

CML is classified as a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is caused by a translocation between BCR (on chromosome 22) and ABL (on chromosome 9) to form a fusion gene. It leads to the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which is characteristic of CML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. t (8;22): Associated with Burkitt lymphoma involving the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8.

 

Option C. t (15;17): Associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), involving the PML and RARA genes.

 

Option D. t (8;14): Also associated with Burkitt lymphoma, involving the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 and the IgH locus on chromosome 14.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The translocation t(9;22) is characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and results in the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which produces the BCR-ABL fusion gene responsible for the disease's pathogenesis.

questions.text: Insulin independent absorption occurs in all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adipose

 

Glucose uptake in adipose tissue is insulin-dependent, primarily using GLUT4 transporters activated by insulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC: Red Blood Cells utilize GLUT1 transporters for glucose absorption, which is insulin-independent and crucial for their energy needs.

 

Option C. Pancreas: While the pancreas plays a role in insulin production, its glucose absorption is not predominantly insulin-independent.

 

Option D. Brain: The brain absorbs glucose independently of insulin, using GLUT3 transporters, essential for its constant energy requirements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose uptake in adipose tissue is insulin-dependent, while RBCs, pancreas, and brain utilize insulin-independent mechanisms for glucose absorption.

questions.text:
Inferior thyroid artery supply which of the following structure?

 

1. Thyroid

2. Parathyroid

3. Esophagus

4. Thymus
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. 1, 2, 3 & 4

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk and arises from the subclavian artery. It runs upward in front of the vertebral column and enters the thyroid gland at its lower pole. Along its course, the inferior thyroid artery gives off several branches that supply the thyroid gland, parathyroid glands, larynx, trachea, esophagus, and the pharynx.

 

  1. Thyroid: The inferior thyroid artery primarily supplies blood to the thyroid gland. The gland requires a substantial blood supply due to its high metabolic activity, especially when it's actively producing thyroid hormones. The inferior thyroid artery enters the thyroid gland at its posterior aspect and supplies the majority of the gland, especially its inferior portion.
  2. Parathyroid: The parathyroid glands are small endocrine glands located on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland. There are usually four parathyroid glands: two superior and two inferior. The inferior parathyroid glands are typically supplied by the inferior thyroid artery. The blood supply to these glands is crucial because they produce parathyroid hormone (PTH), which plays a vital role in calcium homeostasis.
  3. Esophagus: The esophagus, especially its cervical portion, may receive some blood supply from the branches of the inferior thyroid artery. However, it's essential to note that the primary blood supply to the esophagus comes from the esophageal branches of various arteries along its length, such as the aorta and the left gastric artery.
  4. Thymus: While the inferior thyroid artery is not a primary source of blood supply for the thymus, there can be some anastomotic connections between the vessels supplying these structures in the anterior mediastinum. However, the primary blood supply to the thymus comes from the internal thoracic and anterior mediastinal branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thyroid gland receives its main arterial blood supply from the superior and inferior thyroid arteries. The inferior thyroid artery also supplies the parathyroid glands with blood. Additionally, its branches provide blood to the esophagus, larynx, trachea, thymus and pharynx.

 

Branches:

 

  • Pharyngeal branches
  • Ascending cervical artery
  • Inferior artery
  • Muscular branches

 

Thymic branches – originate from internal thoracic, inferior thyroid arteryand often superior thyroid arteries & supply the thymus.

questions.text: Devices which are not used in colorimetric test? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RBC pipette

 

Explanation:

 

The tools shows is the Sahli's method for hemoglobin estimation, a type of colorimetric test.

 

RBC pipette: This device is specifically designed for counting red blood cells and is marked with a red bead. It is not used in hemoglobin estimation via the colorimetric method. The RBC pipette plays no role in this test, which is why it is the correct answer for the device that is not used in this process.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Comparator: This is used to compare the color intensity of the hemoglobin solution with standard color shades to estimate the hemoglobin concentration.

 

Option C. Hemoglobinometer tube: A crucial component of the Sahli's hemoglobinometer, this tube is marked for measuring hemoglobin concentration in percentage and grams per deciliter.

 

Option D. N/10 HCl: This reagent is used to convert hemoglobin into acid hematin, which can then be measured using the colorimetric method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RBC pipette is not used in the Sahli's method of hemoglobin estimation, which employs a colorimetric test involving the hemoglobinometer tube, comparator, and N/10 HCl.

questions.text: Imagine a scenario where a novel medication is introduced that significantly reduces mortality from a specific disease but does not actually cure the disease. As patients continue to live longer with the disease due to this medication, it would have an effect on the epidemiological metrics. Which of the following statements correctly describes the expected change in prevalence and incidence as a result of this medication? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase in prevalence

 

  • The given scenario shows that there is a drug which can reduce mortality but cannot cure a particular disease.
  • So, old cases will live longer and thus, there will be increase in prevalence. Incidence will not get affected due to this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in incidence: Incorrect, as the medication does not affect the rate at which new cases occur.

 

Option B. Decrease in prevalence: Incorrect, since patients living longer with the disease will increase prevalence.

 

Option C. Increase in incidence: Incorrect, because incidence measures new cases, not the duration or survival of existing cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

questions.text: Identify the surgical step shown in the image given below: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capsulorrhexis

 

  • Capsulorrhexis is a step in the conventional extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) method.
  • It is a method of anterior capsulotomy, where an opening is made in the anterior capsule of the lens.
  • Anterior capsulotomy can be done by 3 methods:
    1. Can-opener's technique
    2. Linear capsulotomy or envelope technique
    3. Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis
  • Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis (CCC) is considered superior because it does not leave any edges or tears when done correctly.
  • Trypan blue dye can be used to stain the lens capsule for better visibility during the procedure.
  • In ECCE, a portion of the anterior capsule of the lens is removed, allowing extraction of the lens nucleus and cortex while leaving the remainder of the anterior capsule, the posterior capsule, and the zonular support intact.
  • After capsulorrhexis, hydro dissection is performed using a balanced salt solution to separate the corticonuclear mass from the capsule.
  • Removal of lens nucleus and aspiration of the cortex is done using a two-way irrigation and aspiration cannula.
  • An intraocular lens (IOL) is then implanted, and the incision is closed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrodissection: Hydrodissection involves injecting fluid under the anterior capsule to separate the lens nucleus from the cortex and the capsule. This procedure follows capsulorrhexis and serves to facilitate the removal of the lens material. The image does not show fluid injection or the separation process typical of hydrodissection.

 

Option C. Intraocular lens implantation: This step involves placing an intraocular lens (IOL) into the capsular bag once the lens material has been removed. In the image, there is no indication of an IOL being handled or inserted, as the focus is solely on manipulating the capsule itself, which precedes the IOL implantation in the surgical sequence.

 

Option D. Lens aspiration: Lens aspiration involves the removal of the lens cortex and nucleus, usually through suction or phacoemulsification, following the capsulorrhexis and hydrodissection steps. The image does not depict any equipment or actions associated with the aspiration of lens material, such as a phacoemulsification handpiece or suction device.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capsulorrhexis is characterized by the creation of a controlled and continuous tear in the anterior capsule of the lens, which is essential for accessing and removing the lens material in cataract surgery. This method provides a clear opening without leaving jagged edges, which is crucial for the structural integrity of the remaining capsule necessary for IOL placement.

choices.text: Peutz Jegher syndrome
Villous adenoma
Juvenile polyp

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Juvenile Polyp

 

The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.

 

  • Juvenile (retention) polyps are mucosal epithelial and lamina propria malformations. These can be sporadic or syndromic, but their morphology is often indistinguishable. The vast majority of juvenile polyps are found in children under the age of five. When found in adults, polyps with the same morphology are sometimes referred to as inflammatory polyps. The majority of juvenile polyps are in the rectum and cause painless rectal bleeding.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Puetz Jegher syndrome: Puetz Jegher syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome that manifests as multiple GI hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation at the age of 11 years.

 

 

 

Option B. Villous adenoma: Villous adenomas are neoplastic and present with a different histopathological pattern of finger-like or villous projections.

 

  • They are usually found in older adults and are not typically associated with painless rectal bleeding in children.

 

Option D. Tubular adenoma: Tubular adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that can range from small polyps to large sessile lesions.

 

  • They do not exhibit the cystically dilated glands seen in juvenile polyps and are also more common in older adults.

 

Note - Adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that range in size from small polyps to large sessile lesions. There is no preference for either gender, and both are present in nearly 50% of adults living in the Western world by age 50. Adenomas can be classified as tubular, tubulovillous, or villous based on their architecture.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile polyps are the most common type of rectal polyps in children under five, characterized by cystically dilated crypts and glands, and often present with painless rectal bleeding.

questions.text: What is the approximate time interval between HIV infection & manifestation of AIDS? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 10 years

 

The typical time interval from HIV infection to the manifestation of AIDS, in the absence of antiretroviral therapy, is approximately 10 years. This period is often referred to as the latency period, during which the virus is actively replicating in the body, but the immune system has not yet deteriorated to the point of clinical AIDS. This period can vary based on several factors, including the individual's genetic predisposition, co-infections, and overall health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mean interval b/w infection to AIDS is due to prolonged latency period (~10- years).

 

Reference - Harrison/HIV/Chap 201

questions.text: Which of the following are Methanol poisoning derivatives? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formic acid + Lactic acid

 

Methanol (CH3OH) is metabolized in the body by the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase into formaldehyde (HCHO). This formaldehyde is further converted into formic acid (HCOOH), which is a primary toxic metabolite responsible for the harmful effects of methanol poisoning, including metabolic acidosis, visual disturbances, and organ damage.

 

Furthermore, formic acid inhibits the electron transport chain, particularly at complex IV (cytochrome C oxidase). This inhibition disrupts ATP production, leading to increased levels of NADH. Due to this blockage, pyruvate is converted to lactate, causing the accumulation of lactic acid, another metabolite associated with methanol poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formic acid + Oxalic acid: Oxalic acid is not a metabolite of methanol poisoning but rather of ethylene glycol poisoning. Therefore, this combination is incorrect.

 

Option C. Glycolic acid and Oxalic acid: Both glycolic acid and oxalic acid are metabolites of ethylene glycol poisoning, not methanol poisoning. Hence, this choice is incorrect.

 

Option D. Oxalic acid and Lactic acid: Oxalic acid is not a derivative of methanol poisoning; it is associated with ethylene glycol poisoning. Therefore, this combination is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methanol poisoning primarily results in the formation of formic acid and lactic acid as toxic metabolites.

choices.text: Upper part of right inferior lobe

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the lung is affected when there is aspiration in supine position? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Upper part of right inferior lobe

 

When a person is in the supine position (lying on their back), aspirated material is most likely to enter the superior basel segment of the right lower lobe (upper part of the right inferior lobe). The right main bronchus is wider, shorter, and more vertically oriented than the left main bronchus. This makes the right side more susceptible to aspiration in general. And in the supine position, gravity makes the superior basel segment of the lower lobes (particularly on the right side) the most dependent and thus the most likely site for aspiration.

 

Aspiration of gastric contents can cause chemical pneumonitis or aspiration pneumonia, which can affect different parts of the lung depending on the patient's position during aspiration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lingula: The lingula is a segment of the left upper lobe of the lung. It corresponds anatomically to the right middle lobe but on the left side. Due to the angulation of the main bronchi, it's less common for aspirated contents to travel into the left main bronchus when compared to the right. Thus, while it's possible for aspirated material to reach the lingula, especially in certain positions or conditions, it's not the most common site of aspiration.

 

Option C. Right superior lobe: This lobe isn't the primary location for aspiration in the supine position. However, if someone were to aspirate while standing or sitting upright, aspirated material might be more likely to enter the apical (uppermost) segments of the right upper lobe.

 

Option D. Right middle lobe: The right middle lobe, particularly its bronchus, is more susceptible to aspiration when an individual is in the lateral decubitus position (lying on their side). The lateral segment of the right middle lobe becomes the most dependent segment in this position. But again, in the supine position, the right middle lobe isn't the primary site of aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a patient is in a supine position and aspirates, superior segment of the inferior lobes are the most commonly involved lung sites.

choices.text: Nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation of hip.
Vascular injury is more common in anterior hip dislocation.
Posterior dislocation of hip is more common than anterior.
In posterior hip dislocation, attitude of limb is adduction, flexion and internal rotation.

questions.text: Mark incorrect option: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nerve injury more common in anterior dislocation of hip.

 

 

 

  • “Nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation of hip” – this statement is incorrect. 
  • In posterior hip dislocations, the sciatic nerve is at significant risk of injury. This is the most common nerve injury associated with hip dislocations.
  • In anterior hip dislocations, the femoral nerve or obturator nerve can be injured, but these are generally less common than sciatic nerve injury in posterior dislocations.
  • Therefore, stating nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation is false as it is more common in posterior dislocations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vascular injury more common in anterior hip dislocation. This statement is correct. This is so because the femoral vessels are in close proximity to the hip joint anteriorly, so there are more chances of vascular injury to occur from anterior hip dislocation. Major vascular injuries are rare in both anterior and posterior dislocations. 

 

Option C. Posterior dislocation of hip is more common than anterior. This statement is correct. The incidence of posterior dislocation of hip is around 90%. This is because of the greater strength of anterior ligaments than the posterior ones. 

 

Option D. In posterior hip dislocation, attitude of limb is adduction, flexion and internal rotation. This statement is true. The position of the limb when a patient presents with posterior hip dislocation is of Flexion, Adduction and Internal Rotation i.e., FADIR while in anterior dislocation, it is FABER i.e., Flexion, Abduction and External Rotation. 

 

 

FADIR in posterior hip dislocation

 

Educational Objective:

 

In anterior dislocation of hip, vascular injuries are more common whereas in posterior dislocation, nerve injury (particularly sciatic nerve) is more common.

choices.text: Fasciculation at the level of lesion
Upper motor neuron lesion and lower motor neuron lesion

questions.text: Which of the following does not help in the localization of lesions in the spinal cord? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contralateral hemiplegia

 

When localizing lesions in the spinal cord, it is crucial to understand how different tracts and their associated functions are affected:

 

  1. Corticospinal Tract: Damage to this tract results in ipsilateral hemiparesis (weakness) below the level of the lesion. This is because the corticospinal tract crosses over (decussates) at the medulla, above the spinal cord. Therefore, damage at the spinal cord level affects the same side of the body.
  2. Posterior Column: Damage here leads to ipsilateral loss of light touch, vibration, proprioception, and pressure. Similar to the corticospinal tract, the posterior column pathways decussate above the spinal cord.
  3. Spinothalamic Tract: This tract, responsible for pain and temperature sensation, crosses at the level of the spinal cord itself. Damage to the spinothalamic tract results in contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

 

Given these pathways, contralateral hemiplegia suggests a lesion above the spinal cord, typically above the pyramidal decussation in the brainstem or higher. Therefore, it does not help in localizing lesions within the spinal cord itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fasciculation at the level of lesion: Fasciculations are a sign of lower motor neuron involvement, which can occur at the level of the spinal cord lesion due to damage to the anterior horn cells. This helps in localizing the lesion.

 

Option C. Upper motor neuron lesion and lower motor neuron lesion: The presence of both upper motor neuron (UMN) and lower motor neuron (LMN) signs can be indicative of a spinal cord lesion. UMN signs (such as spasticity and hyperreflexia) occur below the lesion, while LMN signs (such as fasciculations and muscle atrophy) occur at the level of the lesion.

 

Option D. Bladder involvement: Bladder and bowel dysfunction are common in transverse spinal cord lesions. This is due to the involvement of the autonomic pathways that control these functions, helping to localize the lesion within the spinal cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contralateral hemiplegia indicates a lesion above the spinal cord, specifically above the level of pyramidal decussation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was admitted to the hospital after three days of abdominal pain and vomiting. His laboratory reports revealed a potassium value of 3.2 mEq/L. All of the following can be seen except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cerebral edema

 

The patient has hypokalemia, indicated by a potassium level of 3.2 mEq/L.

 

This is not seen with Cerebral edema, which is typically associated with hyponatremia (low sodium levels) rather than hypokalemia. Hyponatremia can lead to an osmotic imbalance, causing water to move into brain cells and resulting in cerebral edema. This is not a recognized complication of hypokalemia.

 

Other options:

 

Hypokalemia can lead to several clinical manifestations:

 

Option A. Ventricular tachycardia: Hypokalemia can cause ventricular arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia, due to its effect on cardiac electrical activity. Potassium is crucial for maintaining normal heart rhythm, and its deficiency can lead to dangerous arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Quadriparesis: Hypokalemia can cause muscle weakness and paralysis, including quadriparesis. It affects muscle function because potassium is essential for normal muscle cell function and nerve transmission. Severe hypokalemia can mimic conditions like Guillain-Barré syndrome.

 

Option C. Diabetes insipidus: Hypokalemia can cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This condition occurs due to a defect in the kidney's ability to respond to antidiuretic hormone (ADH), leading to excessive urination and thirst. Hypokalemia impairs the kidney's concentrating ability, contributing to this disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral edema is not associated with hypokalemia; it is a complication of hyponatremia. Hypokalemia can cause ventricular arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

questions.text:
A patient presents to you with fever, jaundice, and malaise. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the serology reports given below? (NEET PG 2023)

 

  • Anti-HBc (IgM): Positive
  • HBsAg: Positive
  • Anti-HBs: Negative
  • Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute hepatitis B

 

The serology results provide crucial information for diagnosing the type of hepatitis the patient has:

 

  1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): Positive
    • This indicates an active hepatitis B infection, as HBsAg is a marker of infection.
  2. Anti-HBc (IgM) (Hepatitis B core antibody, IgM): Positive
    • The presence of IgM anti-HBc indicates a recent infection or acute hepatitis B. IgM is produced early in the infection and suggests that the infection is recent.
  3. Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): Negative
    • The absence of anti-HBs indicates that the patient has not resolved the infection or been vaccinated. In the context of acute infection, this is expected as the patient has not yet developed immunity.
  4. Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
    • This indicates that the patient does not have hepatitis C.

 

Based on these results, the diagnosis is acute hepatitis B. The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc are key indicators of an acute infection.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Acute hepatitis C: This is ruled out by the negative anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Option C. Chronic hepatitis B: Chronic hepatitis B is diagnosed when HBsAg persists for more than six months and is typically associated with IgG anti-HBc, not IgM.

 

Option D. Chronic hepatitis C: This is ruled out by the negative anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc in a patient with fever, jaundice, and malaise strongly indicates acute hepatitis B.

questions.text: What will be the symptoms of a fracture at the marked area? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anosmia

 

The marked area in the image corresponds to the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone, which is located at the base of the skull. The cribriform plate is a thin, perforated structure through which the olfactory nerves (Cranial Nerve I) pass from the nasal cavity to the olfactory bulbs.

 

If this area is fractured, it can lead to damage to the olfactory nerves, resulting in anosmia, which is the loss of the sense of smell. Anosmia is a common symptom associated with fractures of the cribriform plate, as the olfactory nerves are particularly vulnerable in this region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoacusis: Hypoacusis refers to reduced hearing ability and is typically associated with damage to the auditory structures or the auditory nerve (Cranial Nerve VIII). This symptom is not related to fractures of the cribriform plate.

 

Option B. Visual loss: Visual loss would occur due to damage to the optic nerve (Cranial Nerve II) or structures of the eye, not the cribriform plate. The optic nerve passes through the optic canal, not the cribriform plate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone can lead to anosmia due to damage to the olfactory nerves. This area is crucial for the sense of smell.

choices.text: Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)

questions.text: Transfusing irradiated red blood cells (RBCs) can effectively prevent which of the following conditions? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Graft versus host disease

 

Transfusing irradiated red blood cells (RBCs) can effectively prevent transfusion-associated Graft-Versus-Host Disease (TA-GVHD). TA-GVHD is a rare but serious complication that can occur when viable T lymphocytes present in the transfused blood product proliferate and attack the recipient's tissues. This is particularly dangerous in immunocompromised individuals or those receiving blood from close relatives where the donor lymphocytes are not recognized as foreign by the recipient's immune system.

 

Irradiation of blood products helps to inactivate T lymphocytes, thereby preventing their proliferation and reducing the risk of TA-GVHD. This is crucial in certain patient populations, such as those undergoing bone marrow transplantation, those with congenital immunodeficiency disorders, and patients receiving blood from relatives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HLA alloimmunization: HLA alloimmunization refers to the development of antibodies against human leukocyte antigens (HLA) due to exposure to foreign antigens through transfusions or pregnancy. It is not specifically prevented by irradiating blood products.

 

Option C. Immunomodulation: Immunomodulation refers to the modulation of the immune response by transfused blood products, which is not specifically targeted by irradiation.

 

Option D. Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI): Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is a rare but severe reaction that causes acute respiratory distress following transfusion. It is primarily caused by antibodies in the transfused blood reacting with the recipient's leukocytes, not by the presence of viable T lymphocytes, so irradiation does not prevent TRALI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of irradiated RBCs is specifically recommended to prevent Graft-Versus-Host Disease (GVHD), making it the correct answer for this scenario.

questions.text: A patient presents with urinary crystals as shown in the image below. What can be the cause? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ethylene Glycol

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by the formation of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine. When ethylene glycol is ingested, it undergoes metabolic conversion in the body to glycoaldehyde, which is then converted to glycolic acid, glyxolyic acid, and finally oxalic acid. Oxalic acid combines with calcium in the body to form calcium oxalate crystals. These crystals are excreted in the urine and can cause significant renal damage, potentially leading to renal failure. Additionally, the formation of calcium oxalate crystals depletes calcium levels in the body, leading to symptoms of hypocalcemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methyl Alcohol: Methyl alcohol, or methanol, is metabolized to formaldehyde and formic acid, which primarily cause metabolic acidosis and visual disturbances. It does not lead to the formation of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine.

 

Option C. Aconite: Aconite poisoning affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems, causing symptoms such as hypotension, arrhythmias, and paresthesias. It does not result in the formation of urinary crystals.

 

Option D. Organophosphate poisoning: Organophosphate poisoning affects the nervous system by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, leading to an accumulation of acetylcholine. Symptoms include muscle twitching, respiratory distress, and bradycardia. It does not cause calcium oxalate crystals to form in the urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning leads to the formation of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, which can cause renal failure and hypocalcemia

choices.text: 200-400 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours.
700-900 ml of ORS to be given in the first 4 hours.
In addition to the usual fluid intake, 100-200 ml should be given after each loose stool.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a 9-month-old baby with diarrhea, who is feeding adequately, thirsty, and exhibits skin that returns to normal after a pinch within 2 seconds? [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 400-700 ml of ORS to be given in the first four hours. 

 

  • According to the IMNCI classification, the baby has some dehydration and comes under Plan B. The amount of ORS given is 75ml/kg body weight.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 9-month-old baby showing signs of some dehydration due to diarrhea, it is crucial to administer 400-700 ml of ORS over the first four hours, adhering to IMNCI guidelines. This approach ensures effective initial rehydration and sets the stage for ongoing recovery and feeding.

questions.text: A doctor tells a 31-year-old woman, who is 20 weeks pregnant, that her baby has a developmental defect. She has come to you for a second opinion. The following US finding is seen. Identify the defect? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anencephaly

 

The given ultrasound image shows an open neural tube defect in the calvaria (skull), which is consistent with the diagnosis of anencephaly.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Anencephaly: Results from incomplete closure of the neural tube. It can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation.
    • Ultrasound Signs:
      • Frog eye sign: Absence of cranial calvaria with prominent orbits, resembling the face of a frog.
      • Shower cap sign: Absence of the cranium leading to the protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue, resembling a shower cap and giving rise to a characteristic triangular facial appearance.
    • Prevention: Can be prevented by pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation (5 mg) for at least 3 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Omphalocele: Congenital herniation of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall covered by a membrane. It is different from gastroschisis.

 

Option C. Cystic hygroma: Lymphangioma occurring in the head-neck region.

 

Option D. Encephalocele: Protrusion of the brain and membranes through a cranial defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly is an open neural tube defect characterized by the absence of the cranial calvaria and prominent orbits, detectable by ultrasound as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation. It can be prevented with pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg 201, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg471

choices.text: Deficiency of CD4 T lymphocytes
MHC class II deficiency on lymphocytes
MHC class I deficiency on lymphocytes

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with bare lymphocytic disease. In this patient, graft vs host reaction does not occur due to: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) MHC class II deficiency on lymphocytes

 

 

In BLS 2, the lack of MHC class II expression on lymphocytes means that CD4+ T cells are severely reduced or absent. CD4+ T cells are crucial for initiating and regulating immune responses, including the graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) reaction, where donor immune cells attack the recipient's body. The deficiency of MHC class II molecules, and consequently the absence of CD4+ T cells, prevents GVHD from occurring in patients with BLS 2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complement deficiency: While complement deficiency can lead to immune system problems, it does not directly prevent GVHD. GVHD is primarily driven by T cell responses, particularly CD4+ T cells.

 

Option B. Deficiency of CD4 T lymphocytes: This is a consequence of MHC class II deficiency rather than a cause. The absence of MHC class II molecules leads to a lack of CD4+ T cells.

 

Option D. MHC class I deficiency on lymphocytes: This occurs in BLS 1 and leads to a deficiency in CD8+ T cells, not CD4+ T cells. While this impacts immune function, it does not directly prevent GVHD, which is primarily mediated by CD4+ T cells.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients with Bare Lymphocyte Syndrome type 2 (BLS 2), the absence of MHC class II molecules on lymphocytes results in a lack of CD4+ T cells, preventing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) from occurring.

choices.text: Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – I
Secondary oocyte completed in prophase – II
Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – II
Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase – II

questions.text: Following ovulation, the oocyte remains halted in which meiotic phase until fertilization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Secondary oocyte arrested in metaphase – II

 

After ovulation, the oocyte that is released is the secondary oocyte, which is arrested in metaphase II of meiosis. This arrest continues until fertilization occurs. During fertilization, the entry of sperm triggers the completion of meiosis II, leading to the formation of a mature ovum and the release of the second polar body.

 

This arrest in metaphase II is a crucial step in the reproductive cycle, ensuring that the oocyte is ready to complete meiosis only if fertilization occurs, which prevents the wasteful completion of meiosis without fertilization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – I: This phase describes the primary oocyte that is arrested in prophase I during fetal development and remains in this state until puberty. It is not involved in the post-ovulation phase.

 

Option B. Secondary oocyte completed in prophase – II: This option is incorrect because the secondary oocyte does not complete prophase II. It arrests in metaphase II after ovulation and only completes meiosis II if fertilization occurs.

 

Option C. Primary oocyte arrested in prophase – II: This is incorrect because the primary oocyte does not arrest in prophase II. It arrests in prophase I, and after puberty, it resumes meiosis to form a secondary oocyte.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase II at the time of ovulation and remains in this stage until fertilization occurs, highlighting a critical regulatory checkpoint in the female reproductive cycle.

questions.text: Which inhaled anesthetic agent is preferred for pediatric induction of anesthesia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

 

Sevoflurane is the preferred inhaled anesthetic agent for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients. This is primarily due to its pleasant, sweet smell, which makes it more tolerable for children to inhale. Additionally, Sevoflurane has a rapid onset of action, meaning it works quickly to induce anesthesia. This quick induction is critical in pediatric patients who often do not have an intravenous (IV) line placed before induction. The ability to induce anesthesia effectively and without distress is a significant advantage in this age group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is not preferred for pediatric induction because it has a pungent odor, which can be irritating and unpleasant for children. Moreover, it can cause airway irritation, which is undesirable during induction.

 

Option C. Isoflurane: While Isoflurane is effective as an anesthetic, it also has a pungent smell and slower onset of action compared to Sevoflurane, making it less ideal for pediatric use.

 

Option D. Halothane: Halothane was previously used for pediatric induction, but it has largely fallen out of favor due to its potential for causing liver toxicity and its slower onset of action compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective:


Sevoflurane is the anesthetic agent of choice for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its sweet smell and rapid onset of action.

questions.text: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) is used to relieve pain. What is the mechanism behind it? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gate control theory

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief is based on the gate theory of pain.

 

According to gate control theory, the pain stimuli transmitted by afferent pain fibers are blocked by gate mechanism located at the posterior gray horn of spinal cord. If the gate is opened, pain is felt. If the gate is closed, pain is suppressed.

 

TENS activates a complex neuronal network using electrodes to result in a reduction in pain. At frequencies and intensities used clinically, TENS activates large diameter afferent fibers. This afferent input is sent to the central nervous system to activate descending inhibitory systems to reduce hyperalgesia. Specifically, blockade of neuronal activity in the periaqueductal gray (PAG), rostral ventromedial medulla (RVM) and spinal cord inhibit the analgesic effects of TENS showing that TENS analgesia is maintained through these pathways.

 

The given image depicts the gate control theory of pain:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conditioned pain modulation: This refers to the phenomenon where pain in one part of the body can reduce pain in another part, which is not directly related to the mechanism of TENS.

 

Option C. Descending inhibition: While TENS does activate descending inhibitory pathways, the primary mechanism described in the context of TENS for this question is the gate control theory.

 

Option D. Central inhibition: This refers to the inhibition of pain at the level of the central nervous system, which is a broader concept and not specific to the primary mechanism of TENS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) alleviates pain primarily through the gate control theory, which involves blocking pain signals at the spinal cord level by activating large-diameter afferent fibers.

questions.text: MEN 1 syndrome is associated with:(FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parathyroid tumor

 

MEN 1 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1) syndrome is associated with the development of tumors in endocrine glands, particularly the parathyroid glands, pituitary gland, and pancreatic islet cells. This syndrome is sometimes referred to as the "3 P" syndrome, referring to the involvement of the parathyroid, pituitary, and pancreas.

 

Parathyroid tumors, specifically parathyroid adenomas or hyperplasia, are a characteristic feature of MEN 1 syndrome. These tumors lead to the overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), resulting in primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parotid tumor: Tumors of the parotid gland are not typically associated with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option B. Hepatocellular cancer: MEN 1 syndrome is not directly linked to the development of hepatocellular cancer (liver cancer).

 

Option C. Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytoma, a tumor of the adrenal gland medulla, is associated with MEN 2 syndrome, not MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MEN 1 syndrome, the classic endocrine gland tumors involved are parathyroid tumors (leading to hyperparathyroidism), pituitary adenomas, and pancreatic islet cell tumors (such as gastrinomas and insulinomas). Remembering the "3 P" association (parathyroid, pituitary, and pancreas) can help recall the key features of this syndrome.

 

Familial Syndrome associated with Pheochromocytoma and Extra-adrenal Paragangliomas:

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a noticeable bulge in his lower abdomen that becomes more pronounced when he's in a standing position. Upon examination, hernia is identified located medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what would be the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

 

  • The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of a direct hernia.
  • Direct inguinal hernias protrude through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and are located medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
  • The appropriate surgical method for the management of a direct hernia is the Lichtenstein mesh repair.
  • The Lichtenstein mesh repair is a tension-free technique that uses a synthetic mesh to reinforce the weakened area of the abdominal wall.
  •  It is the preferred method for direct hernias due to its lower recurrence rates and faster recovery times.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct hernia and Bassini repair: While the Bassini repair is a traditional method of hernia repair, it involves suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches or conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament without using a mesh. This technique is mainly used in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis but has a high recurrence rate compared to mesh repairs.

 

Option C. Indirect hernia and Bassini repair: Incorrect. Indirect hernias are located lateral to the inferior epigastric artery and are managed differently. The Bassini repair, as mentioned, is less commonly used today due to its higher recurrence rates compared to mesh repairs.

 

Option D. Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair: Incorrect. While the Lichtenstein mesh repair can also be used for indirect hernias, the scenario describes a direct hernia based on its location medial to the inferior epigastric artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A direct inguinal hernia is characterized by its location medial to the inferior epigastric artery, and the Lichtenstein mesh repair is the recommended surgical approach due to its efficacy and lower recurrence rates.

questions.text: A pituitary tumor that overproduced growth hormone was surgically removed from a patient. The resection was discovered to be insufficient. What is the patient's first-line treatment? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Octreotide

 

Octreotide is a synthetic somatostatin analog that inhibits the secretion of growth hormone (GH) from the pituitary gland. It is the first-line treatment for patients with acromegaly when surgery alone is insufficient to control GH levels. Octreotide binds to somatostatin receptors, reducing GH production and controlling symptoms of acromegaly.

 


Other Options:

 

Option A. Leuprolide: Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist primarily used in the treatment of hormone-sensitive cancers such as prostate cancer, and conditions like endometriosis and uterine fibroids. It is not used for reducing GH levels in acromegaly.

 

Option B. Goserelin: Goserelin is another GnRH agonist used for similar indications as leuprolide, including prostate cancer and breast cancer, as well as for managing endometriosis. It is not indicated for GH reduction in acromegaly.

 

Option C. Nafarelin: Nafarelin also a GnRH agonist, is used for the treatment of endometriosis and central precocious puberty. Like the other GnRH agonists, it is not used to manage GH levels in acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Octreotide is used for the treatment of the following conditions: (SOMATostatin)

 

S: Secretory diarrhea due to carcinoid tumor, VIPomas, following cancer chemotherapy, AIDS etc.

 

O: Oesophageal varices (Acute Variceal bleeding)

 

M: Malignancy like Insulinoma and Glucagonoma

 

A: Acromegaly due to GH secreting pituitary adenoma

 

T: Thyrotrope adenoma

 

  • Leuprolide, Goeserelin and Nafarelin are GnRH agonists.

questions.text: The hormone that does not play a role in the growth of the fetus is: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Growth hormone.

 

Fetal growth is a complex process regulated by various hormones, but growth hormone does not play a significant role in this process during fetal life. The primary hormones involved in fetal growth include insulin, thyroxine, and glucocorticoids.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Insulin: Insulin is crucial for fetal growth, especially during the third trimester. It plays a key role in promoting the storage of nutrients and the growth of fetal tissues, particularly adipose tissue and muscle.
  • Thyroxine: Fetal production of thyroxine begins around the 12th week of gestation. Thyroxine is vital for the development of the central nervous system and overall growth and differentiation of tissues.
  • Glucocorticoids: Glucocorticoids are essential towards the end of gestation, particularly for the maturation of organs such as the lungs, liver, and gastrointestinal tract. They help prepare the fetus for life outside the womb by stimulating the production of surfactant in the lungs and facilitating the maturation of other critical systems.
  • Growth Hormone: Unlike in postnatal life, where growth hormone is a key regulator of growth, its role in fetal growth is minimal. Fetal growth is largely driven by insulin and other growth factors rather than growth hormone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulin and Option C. Thyroxine: Both are crucial for fetal growth, regulating tissue growth and differentiation, especially in the later stages of pregnancy.

 

Option D. Glucocorticoids: These hormones are essential for the maturation of fetal organs before birth, particularly in the liver, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone does not play a significant role in fetal growth, which is primarily regulated by insulin, thyroxine, and glucocorticoids.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroid eye disease

 

Thyroid eye disease (TED), also known as Graves' orbitopathy, is the most common cause of proptosis in middle-aged individuals. TED is an autoimmune condition associated with thyroid dysfunction, typically hyperthyroidism. The disease leads to inflammation and swelling of the extraocular muscles and increased orbital fat, causing the eyes to bulge outward (proptosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital varix: Orbital varices are venous malformations that can cause intermittent proptosis, but they are not the most common cause. They typically become symptomatic during activities that increase venous pressure, such as straining or bending over.

 

Option C. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant intraocular tumor that primarily affects children. It is not a common cause of proptosis in middle-aged adults.

 

Option D. Cavernous hemangioma: Cavernous hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors and the most common orbital tumor in adults, but they are not the most frequent cause of proptosis. These tumors tend to grow slowly and cause progressive proptosis.

 

Intraocular tumours

Most common in adults : Melanoma

Most common in children : Retinoblastoma

 

Intraorbital tumours

Most common in adults : Hemangioma

Most common in children : Rhabdomyosarcoma

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of proptosis in middle-aged individuals is thyroid eye disease (TED), a condition related to thyroid dysfunction that leads to inflammation and swelling within the orbit.

questions.text: 50 yr old gentleman presented with progressive abdominal distension with shifting dullness on examination and dilated veins on lateral chest wall. Ascitic fluid analysis given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Budd-Chiari syndrome

 

Presence of lateral dilated veins with high SAAG, low protein suggests Late Budd-Chiari syndrome.

 

SAAG=Serum albumin- Ascitic Albumin = 2g/dl

 

Interpretation

 

  • ≥1.1: Portal Hypertension (Transudate)
  • <1.1: Exudate

 

Ascitic fluid protein helps identify sinusoidal vs non-sinusoidal causes

 

  • Ascitic fluid protein >2.5 = non-sinusoidal  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Congestive Heart Failure: Typically presents with high SAAG and high protein content in the ascitic fluid.

 

Option C. Cirrhosis: While cirrhosis can also present with high SAAG, it usually shows low protein content in the ascitic fluid, which aligns with this case, but the presence of dilated veins specific to Budd-Chiari provides a more accurate diagnosis.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: Tuberculous peritonitis typically presents with a low SAAG and high protein content, which is inconsistent with the findings in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Hepatology/ascites

questions.text: Confusion assessment test is used in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (often referred to as CAM) is a diagnostic tool specifically designed to identify delirium.

 

CAM is used primarily for the detection of delirium, especially in hospitalized or elderly patients. It evaluates features like acute onset and fluctuating course, inattention, disorganized thinking, and altered level of consciousness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dementia: While CAM can help differentiate delirium from dementia, it is not specifically designed for the diagnosis of dementia.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Depression: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of depression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a tool specifically developed to detect delirium. Bedside examinations such as mini mental status examination (MMSE) are used to provide a measure of cognitive impairment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 701.

choices.text: Kinetic perimetry is used in quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma
In Static perimetry, stimulus intensity is held constant and moved centrally with detection
Visual field defect to be classified as glaucoma, it should have the corresponding optic nerve head abnormalities
Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot

questions.text: Which of these statements is true regarding perimetry? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot


Initial indications of glaucoma in perimetry involve a widespread narrowing of isopters and the appearance of a blockage within the blind spot.

 

Perimetry is a diagnostic test used to assess a person's visual field.

 

Static Perimetry: Traditional method involving fixed stimulus points presented on a static grid. Goldmann perimetry and Humphrey Visual Field Analyzer are common devices for static perimetry.

 

Kinetic Perimetry: Moving stimuli are used to determine the boundaries of the visual field. Useful for mapping the extent of peripheral vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Kinetic perimetry involves moving a stimulus across the visual field to map the boundaries of each isopter. It is not specifically used for quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma; static perimetry is more commonly used for this purpose

 

Option B: In static perimetry, various light spots of different intensities are presented in different locations but do not move across the visual field. The statement in B inaccurately describes kinetic perimetry

 

Option C: While optic nerve head abnormalities are a critical diagnostic feature of glaucoma, visual field defects can exist without clear corresponding optic nerve changes, especially in early or mild cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perimetry is vital for early detection and monitoring of glaucoma. Generalized constriction of isopters and enlargement of the blind spot are key early signs that can indicate the presence of this eye condition.

choices.text: Infundibulum
Ampulla
Isthmus

questions.text: Identify the most common site of implantation in ectopic pregnancy: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ampulla

 

Explanation

 

Ectopic pregnancy refers to implantation occurring outside the endometrial cavity.

 

Sites of implantation

 

 

Uterine (.5%) such as cervical (1%), caesarean scar ectopic <1%)

 

Management of tubal ectopic may be medical or surgical: medical management maybe considered if the patient is haemodynamically stable , foetal cardiac activity absent, beta HCG level less than 5000 , size of gestational sac less than 4 cm .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infundibulum: Accounts for 18% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.

 

Option C. Isthmus: Accounts for 25% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.

 

Option D. Interstitial portion: Accounts for 2% of ectopic pregnancies, but not the most common site.

 

Management of Tubal Ectopic Pregnancy:

 

Management may be medical or surgical:

 

  • Medical Management: Considered if the patient is hemodynamically stable, fetal cardiac activity is absent, beta HCG level is less than 5000, and the size of the gestational sac is less than 4 cm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ampulla of the fallopian tube is the most common site of implantation in ectopic pregnancy, accounting for 55% of cases.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of obstetrics page 207

questions.text: A young male presented with palpitations and hence ECG was taken. ECG demonstrated narrow complex tachycardia and his BP was 70/40 mm of Hg. What is the next step in the management of this patient?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synchronized DC Cardioversion

 

In the case of a patient presenting with palpitations, narrow complex tachycardia, and hypotension (BP 70/40 mm Hg), the patient is considered hemodynamically unstable. The appropriate management for an unstable patient with a pulse is synchronized DC cardioversion. This intervention is critical to restore normal rhythm promptly and prevent deterioration.

 

Synchronized cardioversion delivers a shock that is timed with the QRS complex, preventing the shock from falling on the T wave, which could induce ventricular fibrillation. This is the standard treatment for unstable supraventricular tachycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV Adenosine (6mg): IV Adenosine is used for the treatment of stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not appropriate for an unstable patient due to its transient effect and the need for rapid intervention in unstable conditions.

 

Option C. Carotid Sinus Massage: Carotid sinus massage is a vagal maneuver used to manage stable narrow complex tachycardia. It is not recommended for unstable patients because it may not be effective quickly enough to stabilize the patient.

 

Option D. IV Amiodarone: IV Amiodarone is typically used for stable wide complex tachycardia, especially monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. It is not the first-line treatment for unstable narrow complex tachycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with narrow complex tachycardia, synchronized DC cardioversion is the immediate treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for reversing the effect of muscle relaxation/anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neostigmine

 

Neostigmine is primarily used to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents used during surgery to induce muscle relaxation.

 

Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, meaning it inhibits the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, which normally breaks down acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. By inhibiting this enzyme, neostigmine increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. The excess acetylcholine competes with and displaces the non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers (e.g., rocuronium) from the acetylcholine receptors. As a result, acetylcholine can again bind to the receptors, leading to muscle depolarization and contraction, effectively reversing the muscle relaxation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Succinylcholine: Incorrect because succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker itself and is used to induce muscle relaxation rather than reverse it. It is not used for reversing muscle relaxation.

 

Option C. Glycopyrrolate: Incorrect because glycopyrrolate is an anticholinergic agent used to counteract the side effects of neostigmine, such as bradycardia and bronchospasm. While it is often administered alongside neostigmine, it is not responsible for reversing muscle relaxation.

 

Option D. Atropine: Incorrect because atropine is another anticholinergic agent used to mitigate the side effects of neostigmine, similar to glycopyrrolate. It does not reverse muscle relaxation but helps prevent bradycardia and other cholinergic side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neostigmine is the primary drug used to reverse the effects of non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents, by increasing acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction and allowing muscle contraction to resume.

questions.text: Which is the most common intraocular malignancy in adults? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Choroidal metastasis

 

Explanation:

 

The most common intraocular malignancy in adults is choroidal metastasis.

 

Metastatic tumors to the eye, particularly to the choroid, are more common than primary intraocular malignancies. These metastases usually originate from primary cancers in other parts of the body, such as the breast or lung. The choroid is a vascular layer of the eye that provides a conducive environment for metastatic cells to thrive.

 

The most common primary intraocular malignancy is choroidal melanoma. Choroidal melanoma is the most common primary intraocular cancer in adults, but overall, metastases are more prevalent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinoblastoma: This is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children, not adults.

 

Option B. Choroidal melanoma: While this is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults, it is less common than metastatic tumors overall.

 

Option C. Uveal melanoma: This term encompasses melanomas of the choroid, ciliary body, and iris.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Most common intraocular malignancy in adults - Choroidal melanoma
  • Most common primary intraorbital malignancy in adults -Capillary Hemangioma.
  • Most common primary intraocular malignancy in children – Retinoblastoma
  • Most common intraorbital malignancy in children – Rhabdomyosarcoma

questions.text:
Which of the following are seen in iron deficiency anemia? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Reduced serum iron level
  2. Reduced transferrin saturation
  3. Increased total iron binding capacity
  4. Reduced ferritin level
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) presents with lowered serum iron levels, decreased transferrin saturation, elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), and diminished ferritin levels.

 

1. Reduced Serum Iron

 

  • What it is: This is the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin in the blood.
  • Why it decreases: In IDA, the body's iron stores are depleted due to chronic blood loss, poor dietary intake, or malabsorption, so there's less iron available to circulate.
    • Seen in IDA

 

2. Reduced Transferrin Saturation

 

  • What it is: This is the percentage of transferrin that is bound to iron.
  • Transferrin Saturation=Serum Iron​/TIBC×100
  • Why it decreases: Since serum iron is low and TIBC is high, this ratio drops.
    • Seen in IDA

 

3. Increased Total Iron-Binding Capacity (TIBC)

 

  • What it is: This reflects the maximum amount of iron that transferrin can carry.
  • Why it increases: The liver increases transferrin production in an attempt to capture more iron from the gut when body iron is low.
    • Seen in IDA

 

4. Reduced Ferritin

 

  • What it is: Ferritin is a protein that stores iron in cells and tissues.
  • Why it decreases: In IDA, body iron stores are depleted, so ferritin levels drop.
  • Important point: Ferritin is also an acute-phase reactant and may be elevated in inflammation, but in pure iron deficiency, it is low.
    • Seen in IDA

 

Summary Table

 

 

Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

C. 1, 2, 3, 4 — all of these changes are classical features of iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation.
Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.
Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region

questions.text: Identify the most common neurological complication following ligation of the Inferior mesenteric artery during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sympathetic - retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

 

  • An abdominoperineal resection involves the removal of the left colon, pelvic floor, rectum, and anal canal.
  •  It is typically indicated for patients with operable low rectal carcinomas located within 5 cm of the anal verge.
  • The sympathetic innervation of the rectum originates from L1 – L3 spinal nerves, which form the superior hypogastric plexus.  
  • At the level of the sacral promontory, these nerves divide into the left and right hypogastric nerves, traveling on both sides of the pelvis.
  • These nerves supply the rectum and send branches to supply the genitourinary system anteriorly.
  • During pelvic surgeries, it is crucial to be aware of these nerves to avoid injuring them.
  • High ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) near the sacral promontory may injure the superior hypogastric nerves, leading to sympathetic dysfunction.
  • This dysfunction is characterized by retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parasympathetic - bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation: Parasympathetic nerves are less likely to be affected by the ligation of the IMA as their pathways are different. Parasympathetic innervation primarily involves the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2-S4), which are not typically disrupted in this procedure.

 

Option B. Sympathetic - bladder dysfunction and impotence: While bladder dysfunction is a possible consequence of sympathetic nerve damage, impotence is not the most common result of injury to the sympathetic nerves. The more typical outcome includes retrograde ejaculation.

 

Option D. Sympathetic - Impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region: Loss of cutaneous sensation in the perineal region would more likely result from damage to the pudendal nerve, not the sympathetic nerves. Impotence can occur but is less specific compared to retrograde ejaculation in the context of IMA ligation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma, ligation of the inferior mesenteric artery may lead to sympathetic nerve damage, particularly the superior hypogastric plexus.
  • This can result in neurological complications such as retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction.

questions.text: A chronic smoker was on nicotine replacement therapy and clonidine tablets for smoking de-addiction. He stopped taking clonidine tablets and now presents with a headache. What is the reason behind this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rebound hypertension

 

Clonidine is an alpha-2 agonist and a centrally acting antihypertensive agent. Used in HTN. Stimulates presynaptic α-receptor in the vasomotor centre in the brainstem, suppressing the release of norepinephrine and other sympathomimetics.

 

Clonidine sudden stoppage causes Rebound HTN and sympathetic overactivity.

 

Treatment of clonidine withdrawal is Phentolamine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postural Hypotension

 

  • Description: A condition where blood pressure drops significantly upon standing up.
  • Relevance: Clonidine can cause postural hypotension, but sudden discontinuation leads to rebound hypertension, not postural hypotension.

 

Option B. Receptor Upregulation

 

  • Description: An increase in the number of receptors on the cell surface.
  • Relevance: This concept is more related to long-term exposure to antagonists, not the sudden withdrawal of an agonist like clonidine.

 

Option D. Receptor Hypersensitivity

 

  • Description: Increased sensitivity of receptors to a stimulus.
  • Relevance: While receptor hypersensitivity can occur, it is not the primary mechanism behind the headache and rebound hypertension seen with sudden clonidine withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rebound hypertension is a critical condition that can occur when clonidine, an alpha-2 agonist, is suddenly discontinued. This results in a rapid increase in sympathetic activity, leading to symptoms such as headache due to a sudden spike in blood pressure.

questions.text: Identify the finding associated with the condition shown in the image below which is characterized by development of morphologically similar lesions along the lines of trauma:  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Isomorphic phenomenon

 

  • It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin.
  • The new lesions have iso(same) & morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.

 

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

 

 

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

 

 

Some rare causes of true Koebner phenomenon are:

 

Darier’s disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, EMF erythema multiforme, Kaposi’s sarcoma & lichen nitidus.

 

Reverse Koebner phenomenon or Renbeok phenomenon:

 

Seen in psoriasis. The area of psoriasis clears & heals following injury (trauma).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Gottron's papule seen associated with Dermatomyositis.

 

Option B. Nikolsky Sign

 

Description: Positive when the superficial epidermis moves laterally with slight rubbing or pressure, leading to the separation of the epidermis from the underlying dermis as shown in the below image.

 

 

 

Option D: Meyerson phenomenon is a melanocytic nevus that has developed an eczematous ring around it as seen in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isomorphic phenomenon (Koebner phenomenon) as the appearance of skin lesions similar to a primary disease along areas of skin trauma, which is important for diagnosis and management in dermatology.

 

References:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 123.2
